pros:

pros: Allows one to work in challenging environments
cons: They rarely if ever, listen to employee opinions

pros: Get to support the refugee problem which is a huge global problem.
cons:
- Lack of unrestricted funds to allow flexibility to do new project and grow efforts into other humanitarian efforts.
- HQ does not seem to exist to help field operations. It seems there to ensure that field staff does not mistakes and to ensure fund execution since HQ has to live "hand to mouth" from the small overhead fees from grants. Not very innovative nor creative in business practices. M&E staff let go due to lack of funding which is a red flag since M&E is critical to show relevancy of work to donors.
- No strong standardized policies and procedures which causes confusion and frustrations since procedures can be interpreted differently by different individuals. Different sites have different procedures and policies.
- At field level, there seems to be a distrust of local staff. Little is done to build their capacity to ensure that they can be developed. Local salaries are generally lower than other bigger NGOs which causes a fear of loss of talent.
- Organization of senior field management seems designed for conflict rather than team building. For instance, Program Coordinator, Finance Controller and Logistics are all separate at equal levels. This is okay in some instances but if there is disagreement, this causes the system to break down. This is exacerbated by the lack of standardized procedures.
- Focus seems to be on re-branding image and program development rather than effective implementation of programs.

pros: Rwanda Country Program was doing very well
cons: Racist , poor funding and staff welfare

review_title: They act nice, but do not treat employees well
pros: Learn a lot, possibility for travel, meaningful work
cons: compensation, advancement, misuse of funds, employee egos get in the way of getting work done. I started as an unpaid intern (which is of course illegal, really) and when I finally got a paid position it was ridiculously low, barely a living wage. Senior staff didn't take the time to learn interns' names (and the headquarters office is tiny, so there was no excuse for this). I was under-utilized by supervisors. Instead of designing or improving programs, I was given menial tasks like editing terribly written reports

pros: Position was in ARC's Development & Communications department. Great colleagues who were driven, fast paced, intelligent, and good-humored. Good management with opportunity to take on passion projects once you prove yourself. Had good comradery with other departments and field staff. The organization is doing good work - Would work there again!
cons: Can be longer hours, don't expect a 9-5. Retirement contribution doesn't kick in until you have been 'full time' for a year.

pros:
Ability to work with team members around the world, either through passion projects or regular interaction on the different WhatApp channels used internally. 

Was able to transition from a national role into an HQ position, which i have appreciated a lot. It gave me extra responsibilities to work with colleagues on the international stage. 

I am able to work remotely and my boss is very flexible and understanding.
cons: Interview process can't feel long at times but it's worthy it in the end when you are hired

review_title: Limited Responsibilities with little-to-no guidance or inclusion
pros: Organization has a terrific vision and impact, with talented people dedicated to their  jobs.
cons: As an unpaid intern you expect to be compensated in experience and knowledge, but what you end up with is only what you can gather yourself.  Apart from the printed list of weekly tasks, no time is spent guiding or integrating interns into the actual work that is done in international development and humanitarian aid.   If anything you will only develop mild skills in excel.

review_title: Great organization and programs - dysfunctional HQ
pros: MN is great place to live. Overseas programs do a lot of good work.

pros: Small but expanding organization. Nice place to start career.
cons: Poor Management especially one anonymous notorious Country Director. Bad attitude, unprofessional, incompetent and full of witchhunting.  Mistreats lower level employees and seems to derive extreme pleasure from that. Perpetually in trouble with professionals who know their rights and do not want to be pushed around. So many have had to quit because of disagreements with this gentleman.

pros: HQ has some great, talented staff and the organization is set up to have a fun, motivating culture.
cons: As the case with most humanitarian NGOs, there are limited resources and being short-staffed makes for heavy work loads.

review_title: High turnover. Employees are treated poorly.

review_title: For Field Work, research the country office before going
pros: A lot of autonomy and personal responsibility.
cons: A shrinking budget for the office I worked in that made daily operations difficult.  I wish I knew more about the situation before I went.

pros: ARC is relatively small which allows the individual more influence than they would have in bigger organizations. Great opportunity to grow for fresh graduates.
cons: limited opportunities to grow for more experienced, Senior Management Team members

cons: Fast turnover rate but that is typical in the humanitarian aid field. Not very inclusive.
